creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture; formerly given to the Center by Mr and Mrs Ian Wilson
description: four full lines and a fifth broken line at far L of cursive characters; gold, teal, and beige mount
inscription:
時守可つづみ打霞む春能夜乃月にうかべる大宮所(*皇居=京都御所)
香りな袖に裳耒な計鶯乃心しぐるる雨耳我立ぬ連し
鳥能跡牛能また連乃計可さすハ都大路盤貴與与から満し越
貴けバ知りミ礼ば得多りと??乃道盤父よ理ふみまふらん　
(The timekeeper beats his hand drum
The Imperial Palace is floating perched on a hazy moon of a spring night.

Like the heart of a bush warbler with scentless sleeves without Mo (ancient women’s trousers)
In a spring shower, I am standing and soaking wet.

Divinatory shows, after the hour of the Cock (5-7 pm), before the hour of the Ox (2 am) 
The Great Avenue would be pure.

When I listen, I understand, when I see I get, on the road of _ _  (two unreadable characters)
I will not go in the wrong direction like my father did.

- My most recent four poems.)
title: Four Waka Poems
